originInfo.publisher: Louisiana. Dept. of Wildlife and Fisheries

mods.abstract: A typical pond created in brackish marsh by a sever muskrat eat-out. The vegetation is winegrass (Spartina patens)" Marshes broken to this extent generally remain unproductive for long periods unless artificially drained. This particular area was eaten-out in 1939,"(Photo taken 1942), and revegetated during the drought of July, August, and September 1947. It is possible that under excellent management, this area will carry a normal 'rat population by 1950-51.

titleInfo.title: Louisiana Sea Grant Digital Images Collection

mods.note: ONeil, T. The muskrat in the Louisiana coastal marshes: a study of the ecological, geological, biological, tidal, and climatic factors governing the production and management of the muskrat industry in Louisiana. New Orleans: Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries, 1949.
